title: Why do we have a conventional name and scientific name for every species? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not every species has a conventional name. Not even close. Scientific names are a way to standardize the naming of species, so that when a scientist uses a scientific name every other scientist will understand exactly what species they are referring to and there is no potential for confusion because a species has exactly one scientific name. It’s standardized. In the tarantula keeping hobby and scorpion keeping hobby it is standard practice to use scientific names. This is often confusing and annoying to newcomers; after all they’d rather learn names like “whitestriped birdeater” and “Mexican red-knee” than Acanthoscuria geniculata and Brachypelma hamorii. The common names are so much easier and cooler sounding right? Wrong, at least in the long-run. You see, most tarantulas species do not have a standardized common name. If you are told a common name for a tarantula by the person who sold it to you, nine times out of ten they made the name up on the spot. Same thing applies when you see a common name for a tarantula on a sign at the zoo. And in a hobby where tarantulas vary wildly by temperament, environmental requirements, and venom toxicity, this can be dangerous. It is imperative that you know exactly what you are getting. If you bought a “rust-red bird-eater” and thought you were buying Lasiodora parahybana but actually received Hysterocrates gigas, you’re gonna have a really bad time. Also, if you don’t know the scientific name good luck finding anything of value on the internet about caring for the species.  Pictured: Ybyrapora diversipes, a beautiful tarantula with no common name.

All species known to science have a scientific name but not all species that have scientific names, have conventional names. Ladies and gentlemen: Silurian polychaete worm Kingnites diamondi[1].  Image from 10 tons DK. Giving funny, unusual, intriguing scientific names to newly discovered species is a bit of a “marketing”. It draws attention to newly discovered species, that might not otherwise be ever noticed. It also draws attention to the scientist that discovered it. And why not? Footnotes[1] Swedish Scientist Names Newly Discovered Species After King Diamond
